title-group.article-title: History's Implosions: A Benjaminian Reading of Ambedkar

permissions.copyright-statement: Copyright 2001 JNT: Journal of Narrative Theory

ref.mixed-citation: Foucualt's reading of modernity in "What is Enlightenment?" where he says, "Modernity is not a phenomenon of sensitivity to the fleeting present; it is the will to 'heroize' the present" (40)
Intimate Enemy: Loss and Recov- ery of Self Under Colonialism, xv

Marxist Dalit Panther poet-activist, Namdev Dhasal's position which reads Ambedkar's conversion as a ruse/strategy to mobilize the common man: "Con- version to Buddhism ... freed the Scheduled Castes from mental and psychological enslavement. ... Religion (has) an attraction for the common man and it is not easy to change his attitude toward it" (Zelliot 219)
"Translating Life-Worlds into Labour and History," Provincializing Europe
Hermann Oldenberg, London: Williams and Norgate 1: 86-87
John S. Strong, The Experience of Buddhism: Sources and Interpretation, 61-62

Strong in his preface to the story writes: "In ancient India, where belief in the ability of deities, dead spirits and supernatural beings of various sorts to take on human form was widespread, this rule made good sense, and to this day, in South and Southeast Asia, candidates are routinely asked as part of the ritual preliminaries for higher ordination, the intriguing question "Are you a human being?" (61)
